Southerner Donald Writes on Southerners
By RALPH MOLLER
With his soft Southern drawl, you
can easily imagine David Donald as
an aristocratic Mississippi plantation owner.
Yet Donald, who won the Pulitzer
prize for his book "Charles Sumner
and the Coming of the Civil War,"
is
professor of History and director of
the Institute of Southern History at
Hopkins.
Donald, raised in Mississippi, is
steeped in Southern tradition. His
leadership in his field is challenged
only by a fellow Southerner, C. Van
Woodward.
Donald said being brought up in
the South has helped him in his
work. "I find it very difficult," he
remarked, "when approaching a
subject like the Civil War or slavery
to think in rather clear
moralistic
terms, of good or bad, or of right or
wrong.
"If you're brought
in a society
where you see arouna you inherited
Prejudices and animosities, you
realize that nobody sat down and
created them, but that this was the
order of things into which you were
born.
How They Feel
"I think that I can feel how
Southerners felt at that time. You
don't necessarily agree with them,
but you see how it
occurs."
Donald attended Millsaps College
in
Mississippi. At the small school,
Donald met a dynamic professor of
History and Reconstruction who

sparked his interest in the subject.
"He was so exciting, so disturbing
in this rather rural Mississippi area
that all of us young men clustered
around him," Donald related.
Southern history became his
specialty largely because of his
origins. "For a Mississippian, the
South, and how it got to be the South
and why it continues to be the South-these are obsessive questions," he
said.

"I have no need of
finding my identity
in Southern past."
Dr. Donald did his graduate work
at the University of Illinois, where
he studied under the Lincoln expert
J. G. Randall. "He persuaded me
that in order to understand the
Reconstruction period, you have to
understand what went on before the
Reconstruction--events before and
during the War.
"So that in a certain sense the rest
of my life has been a long running
start to get ready for Recon-

struction."
Historic Rivalry
Dr. Donald has an intense rivalry
in Southern history with Yale
historian C. Vann Woodward, author
of "The Strange Career of Jim
Crow."
Donald described Woodward as
being much more class-oriented
than he. "I emphasize much more
strongly psychological and nonrational elements," he explained.
Woodward, according to Donald,
has a tendency to remake Southern
history to his own liking. "Professor
Woodward seeks in the South and its
history his own identity," he
charged. "That is, he is a Southern
liberal and he would like to seek a
vindication of his own stand."
And Donald quietly noted, "I, to
the contrary, have no such need of
finding my identity in the Southern
past."
He mentioned that many people
have tried to compare the Civil War
with the present political situation.
But he claimed the situation is not
nearly as extreme now.
"The news," he said, "has played
up a relatively small group of
students till we think that the end of
the world is around the corner."
Peace and Tranquility
"I think that elections in
November will indicate that peace
and tranquility, moderation, middle
of the road policies--that these are
the dominant attitudes in American
society."

Lab Program Mixed Success

Presently, Donald is working on a
book to be published in November
called "Charles Sumner and the
Rights of Man." Donald's interest in
Charles Sumner stems from the
abolitionist's ability to be an
idealistic reformer and still wield
power.
Dr. Donald noted, "My book is
about a chairman of the Senate
Foreign Relations Committee who
opposes an unjust war and
segregation.
"I just might send Senator
Fulbright a personal copy," he
mused.

That internal dissension within a department could
lead to that department's abolition should be unthinkable. But it happened here in the case of Education.
There has been considerable debate at Hopkins over
the years on whether or not the Education Department
made a sufficient contribution to the academic community to warrant its maintenance. But the resolution of
that debate was not the factor that led to the department's demise.
In fact, Dr. John Walton, a senior professor in
Education, convinced the Academic Council several
years back to import a chairman--Timothy Smith--to
give the department new life. Allegations against Dr.
Smith's conduct as chairman are now worthless history.
The Education Department is going and it is highly
doubtful anything can be done at this stage to save it.
The question we should all consider is why the
situation was allowed to get so far out of hand that the
Academic Council felt there was nothing to be done,
save abolish what we consider a vital department.
The answer is unchecked departmental autonomy.
Important academic decisions at Hopkins are made at
the departmental level, and each faculty member seems
to be so interested in preserving his own and department's freedom that he is willing to turn his back on
another department's troubles until the very magnitude
of those troubles spills over into his daily life.
This is what happened with Education. The internal
squabbling that wracked the department could be, and
was, ignored for many years. When the Academic
Council finally decided to look, it had no choice but to see
a problem out of hand.
Let's not allow what happened to Education happen
again. We urge more open academic governance and
the inclusion of students, graduate and undergraduate,
on departmental decision-making panels.
Departmental affairs other than hiring, should,
wherever possible, be made open to the Hopkins community. Students may not be qualified to make final
decisions on hiring, but they are certainly well-qualified
to add valuable insights on the teaching credentials on
department members--and maybe also save the
department.

Education's Moral
That internal dissension within a department could
lead to that department's abolition should be unthinkable. But it happened here in the case of Education.
There has been considerable debate at Hopkins over
the years on whether or not the Education Department
made a sufficient contribution to the academic community to warrant its maintenance. But the resolution of
that debate was not the factor that led to the department's demise.
In fact, Dr. John Walton, a senior professor in
Education, convinced the Academic Council several
years back to import a chairman--Timothy Smith--to
give the department new life. Allegations against Dr.
Smith's conduct as chairman are now worthless history.
The Education Department is going and it is highly
doubtful anything can be done at this stage to save it.
The question we should all consider is why the
situation was allowed to get so far out of hand that the
Academic Council felt there was nothing to be done,
save abolish what we consider a vital department.
The answer is unchecked departmental autonomy.
Important academic decisions at Hopkins are made at
the departmental level, and each faculty member seems
to be so interested in preserving his own and department's freedom that he is willing to turn his back on
another department's troubles until the very magnitude
of those troubles spills over into his daily life.
This is what happened with Education. The internal
squabbling that wracked the department could be, and
was, ignored for many years. When the Academic
Council finally decided to look, it had no choice but to see
a problem out of hand.
Let's not allow what happened to Education happen
again. We urge more open academic governance and
the inclusion of students, graduate and undergraduate,
on departmental decision-making panels.
Departmental affairs other than hiring, should,
wherever possible, be made open to the Hopkins community. Students may not be qualified to make final
decisions on hiring, but they are certainly well-qualified
to add valuable insights on the teaching credentials on
department members--and maybe also save the
department.

A political deal may be in the making to prevent
democratically elected Salvadore Allende, a
